column1: As an experiment illustrating the advantage of this: let a camera be placed close to the wall
column2: then the sitter arranged so that from that point of view a three-quarter face is obtained
column3: and it will be noticed that there is very little need of the reflector at all. Let a negative now be taken
column9: turned round until a similar view of the face is obtained from that point. It will now be seen that the shadows are very much deeper than before
column10: and the reflector will have to be brought pretty close in order to overcome them; nevertheless they may be obtained quite as soft and harmonious as in the former case. Let a second negative now be taken
column11: giving the same exposure as before
column12: and it will be found that if the first one were correctly timed the second will be considerably under-exposed. Yet the sitter was at the same distance from the window in each case.
